In following him; and yet I'll never leave him,
I'll crawl of all four first; my cause is meritorious,
And come what can come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: All you have told me is certain;
Complexion, and all else.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: It may be she then;
And I'll so fumble her: is she grown mad now?
Is her blood set so high? I'll have her madded,
I'll have her wormed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mark but the end, old master,
If thou beest not sick oth' bots within these five hours,
And kickest and roarest; I'll make ye fart fire, signior,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's one oth' house, a fool, an idiot sir;
May be she is going home; she'll be a guide to ye;
And so I kiss your hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O now I am lost, lost, lost, lord, how I tremble!
My father, armed in all his hates and angers;
This is more misery than I have scaped yet.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Fool, fool.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He knows me not; will ye give me twopence?
And gaffer, here's a crowflower, and a daisy;
I have some pie in my pocket too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: This is an arrant fool,
An ignorant thing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Believe so, and I am happy.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Dost thou dwell in Sigonia, fool?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No no, I dwell in heaven.
And I have a fine little house, made of marmalade.
And I am a lone woman, and I spin for saint Peter;
I have a hundred little children, and they sing psalms with me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: 'Tis pity this pretty thing should want understanding.
But why do I stand talking with a coxcomb?
If I do find her, if I light upon her,
I'll say no more. Is this the way to th' town, fool?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You must go over the top of that high steeple, gaffer.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: A plague of your fool's face.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, take her counsel.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And than you shall come to a river twenty mile over,
And twenty mile and ten: and than you must pray, gaffer;
And still you must pray, and pray.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pray heaven deliver me
From such an ass, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Amen, sweet gaffer.
And fling a sop of sugar-cake into it;
And than you must leap in naked.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would he would believe her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And sink seven days together; can ye sink gaffer?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Yes coxcomb, yes; prithee farewell: a pox on thee.
A plague of that fool too, that set me upon thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then I'll bring you a sup of milk shall serve ye:
I am going to get apples.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Go to th' devil:
Was ever man tormented with a puppy thus?
Thou tell me news? thou be a guide?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then nunkle —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Prithee keep on thy way (Good naunt) I could rail now
These ten hours at mine own improvidence:
Get apples, and he choked: farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Farewell nuncle.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I rejoice in any thing that vexes him;
And I shall love this fool extremely for't:
Could I but see my mistress now, to tell her
How I have truly, honestly wrought for her,
How I have worn myself away, to serve her.
Fool, there's a royal for the sport thou madest me,
In crossing that old fool, that parted from thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou art honest sure; but yet thou must not see me:
I thank ye little gentleman: heaven bless ye
And I'll pray for ye too: pray ye keep this nutmeg,
'Twas sent me from the lady of the mountain.
A golden lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How prettily it prattles.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: 'Tis very good to rub your understanding:
And so good night: the moon's up.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Pretty innocent.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now fortune, if thou dar'st do good, protect me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll follow him to yond town: he shall not scape me:
Stay, I must counterfeit a letter by the way first,
And one that must carry some credit with it: I am wide else,
And all this to no purpose that I aim at.
A letter must be had, and neatly handled:
And then if goodwife fortune do not fail me,
Have at his skirts: I shall worse anger him
Then ever I have done, and worse torment him.
It does me good to think how I shall conjure him.
And crucify his crabbedness: he's my master,
But that's all one: I'll lay that on the left hand.
He would now persecute my harmless mistress,
A fault without forgiveness, as I take it;
And under that bold banner flies my vengeance,
A meritorious war, and so I'll make it.
I'th' name of innocence, what's this the fool gave me?
She said 'twas good to rub my understanding.
What strange concealment? Bread or cheese, or a chestnut?
Ha! 'tis a ring: a pretty ring, a right one:
A ring I know too! the very same ring:
Oh admirable blockhead! O base eyes!
A ring my mistress took from me, and wore it;
I know it by the posy: prick me, and heal me.
None could deliver this, but she herself too:
Am I twice sand-blind? twice so near the blessing
I would arrive at? and block-like never know it?
I am vengeance angry, but that shall light on thee,
And heavily, and quickly, I pronounce it:
There are so many cross ways, there's no following her:
And yet I must not now: I hope she is right still,
For all her outward show, for sure she knew me;
And in that hope, some few hours I'll forget her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is not to be recovered, which I vex at;
And he beyond my vengeance, which torments me:
O! I am fooled and slighted, made a rascal;
My hopes are flattered, as my present fortunes:
Why should I wander thus and play the coxcombs?
Tire out my peace and pleasure for a girl?
A girl that scorns me too? A thing that hates me?
And considered at the best, is but a short breakfast
For a hot appetite: why should I walk, and walk thus,
And fret myself, and travel like a carrier,
And peep, and watch? want meat, and wine, to cherish me,
When thousand women may be had, ten thousand,
And thank me too, and I sit still: well, trim beauty
And chastity, and all that seem to ruin me,
Let me not take ye; let me not come near ye,
For I'll so trim ye: I'll so bustle with ye;
'Tis not the name of virgin shall redeem ye,
I'll change that property: nor tears, nor angers:
I bear a hate about me scorns those follies.
To find this villain too, for there's my main prize;
And if he snap me then.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is not that Pedro?
'Tis he, 'tis he: o!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha? now, now, now,
Oh now most miserable.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What of devil art thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No end of my misfortunes, heaven?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What antic?
Speak puppet, speak.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: That habit to betray me?
Ye holy saints, can ye see this?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It danceth:
The devil in a fool's coat, is he turned innocent?
What mops, and mows it makes: heigh, how it frisketh,
Is't it not a fairy? or some small hobgoblin?
It has a mortal face, and I have a great mind to it,
But if it should prove the devil then.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Come hither.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I think 't will ravish me,
It is a handsome thing, but horribly sunburnt,
What's that it points at?

sp.speaker: Alin,
sp.l: Dost thou see that star there,
That, just above the sun;
Prithee go thither, and light me this tobacco,
And stop it with the horns o'th' moon.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The thing's mad,
Abominably mad, her brains are buttered,
Go sleep, fool, sleep.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou canst not sleep so sweetly:
For so I can say my prayers, and then slumber.

body.l: I am not proud, nor full of wine,
This little flower will make me fine:
Cruel in heart, for I shall cry,
If I see a sparrow die:
I am not watchful to due ill,
Nor glorious to pursue it still:
Nor pitiless to those that weep;
Such as are, bid them go sleep.
Do, do, do, and see if they can.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It said true,
I feel it sink into me forcibly.
Sure 'tis a kind of Sibyl, some mad prophet.
I feel my wildness bound, and fettered in me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Give me your hand, and I'll tell you what's your fortune.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Here: prithee speak.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, fie, fie.
Wash your hands, and pare your nails, and look finely
You shall never kiss the King's daughter else.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I wash 'em daily.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: But still you foul 'em faster.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This goes nearer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You'll have two wives.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Two wives?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I two fine gentlewomen.
Make much of 'em: for they'll stick close to you sir.
And these two, in two days.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That's a fine riddle.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Today you shall wed sorrow,
And repentance will come tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sure she's inspired.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I'll sing ye a fine song sir.
He called down his merry men all
By one, by two, by three,
William would fain have been the first,
But now the last is he.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This the mere chronicle of my mishap.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I'll bid you good e'en: for my boat stays for me yonder,
And I must sup with the moon tonight in the mediterraneum. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: When fools, and mad-folks shall be tutors to me,
And feel my sores, yet I unsensible;
Sure it was set by providence upon me
To steer my heart right: I am wondrous weary.
My thoughts too, which add more burden to me:
I have been ill, and (Which is worse) pursued it,
And still run on: I must think better, nobler,
And be another thing, or not at all. Enter four peasants.
Still I grow heavier, heavier heaven defend me:
I'll lie down, and take rest: and goodness guard me.

sp.speaker: Pes. 1
sp.l: We have scaped today well: certain, if the outlaws
Had known we had been stirring, we had paid for't,
Plague on 'em, they have robbed me thrice,
And me five times:
Beside they made my daughter one of us too
An arrant drum: oh, they are the lewdest rascals,
The captain such a damned piece of iniquity:
But we are far enough of on 'em, that's the best on't,
They cannot hear.
They'll come to me familiarly
And eat up all I have: drink up my wine too,
And if there be a servant that content 'em,
Let her keel hold, they'll give her stowage enough:
We have no children now, but thieves, and outlaws.
The very brats in their mother's bellies have their qualities.
They'll steal into the world.
Would we had some of 'em here,
Ay, of that condition we could master 'em,
They are sturdy knaves.
A devil take their sturdiness,
We can neither keep our wives from 'em, nor our states,
We pay the rent, and they possess the benefit.
What's this lies here? is it drunk, or sober?
It sleeps, and soundly too.
'Tis an old woman
That keeps sheep hereabouts: it turns, and stretches.
Does she keep sheep with a sword?
It has a beard too.
Peace, peace: it is the devil Roderigo,
Peace of all hands, and look.
'Tis he
Speak softly,
Now we may fit him.
Stay, stay: let's be provident.
Kill him, and wake him then.
Let me come to him,
E'en one blow at his pate, if ere he wake more.
So, so, so, lay that by.
I must needs kill him.
It stands with my reputation
Stand off, I say:
And let us some way make him sure; then torture him.
To kill him presently, has no pleasure in't.
Has been tormented of us, at least this twelvemonth .

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He comes: he comes.
Has he no guns about him?
Softly again: no, no: take that hand easily,
And tie it fast there: that to th' other bough there.
Fast, fast, and easy lest he wake.
Have we got ye?
This was a benefit we never aimed at.
Out with your knives, and let's carve this cock-thief,
Daintily carve him.
I would he had been used thus
Ten year ago; we might have thought we had children.
O, that sir Nicholas now our priest were here.
What a sweet homily would he say over him,
For ringing all in with his wife in the belfrey?
He would stand up stiff girt: now pounce him lightly,
And as he rores, and rages, let's go deeper:
Come near: you are dim eyed: on with your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O, what torments me thus? what slaves, what villains?
O spare me, do not murder me.
We'll but tickle ye,
You have tickled us at all points.
Where are his emblems? Enter Pedro

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As ye are men, and Christians
Yes we hear ye,
And you shall here of us too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What noise is this? what roar? I cannot find her,
She is got free again: but where, or which way?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: On villains, beasts.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Murdering a man, ye rascals?
Ye inhumane slaves, off, off, and leave this cruelty,
Or as I am a gentleman: do ye brave me?
Then have among ye all, ye slaves, ye cowards,
Take up that sword, and stand: stay ye base rascals,
Ye cutthroat rogues.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Away, away. Exeunt Pes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye dog-whelps:

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: On I am how more wretched far, then ever.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A violence to that habit? ha? Roderigo,
What makes he here, thus lad? is it repentance,
Or only a fair show to guide his mischiefs?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This benefit has made me shame to see him,
To know him, blush?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You are not much hurt?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No sir;
All I can call a hurt, sticks in my conscience,
That pricks, and tortures me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Have ye considered
The nature of these men, and how they used ye?
Was it fair play? did it appear to you handsome?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I dare not speak: or if I do, 'tis nothing
Can bring me off, or justify me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Was it noble
To be o'erlaid with odds, and violence?
Manly, or brave in these thus to oppress ye?
Do you blush at this, in such as are mere rudeness,
That have stopped souls, that never knew things gentle?
And dare you glorify worse in yourself sir?
Ye used me with much honour, and I thank ye,
In this I have requited some: ye know me:
Come turn not back, ye must, and ye shall know me;
Had I been over seasoned with base anger,
And suited all occasions to my mischiefs,
Bore no respect to honesty, religion,
No faith, no common tie of man, humanity,
Had I had in me, but given reins, and licence
To a tempestuous will, as wild as winter,
This day, know Roderigo, I had set
As small a price upon thy life, and fortunes,
As thou didst lately on mine innocence;
But I reserve thee to a nobler service.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I thank ye, and I'll study more to honour ye:
You have the nobler soul, I must confess it,
And are the greater master of your goodness.
Though it be impossible I should now recover,
And my rude will grow handsome in an instant,
Yet touching but the pureness of your mettle,
Something shall show like gold, at least shall glister,
That men may hope, although the mine be rugged,
Stony, and hard to work: yet time, and honour
Shall find and bring forth that, that's rich and worthy.

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: I'll try that: and to'th purpose: ye told me sir
In noble emulation, so I take it;
I'll put your hatred far off, and forget it,
You had a fair desire to try my valour:
You seemed to court me to it; you have found a time,
A weapon in your hand, an equal enemy,
That, as he puts this off, puts of all injuries,
And only now for honour's sake defies ye:
Now, as you are a man, I know you are valiant,
As you are gentle bred, a soldier fashioned.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: His virtue startles me. I dare fight Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And as you have a mistress that you honour,
Mark me, a mistress.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A handsome mistress,
As you dare hold yourself deserving of her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Deserving? what a word was that to fire me?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I could compel ye now without this circumstance,
But I'll deal free, and fairly, like a gentleman:
As ye are worthy of the name ye carry,
A daring man.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O that I durst not suffer:
For all I dare do now, implies but penance.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now do me noble right.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I'll satisfy ye:
But not by th'word: pray ye hear me, and allow me;
I have been rude: but shall I be a monster,
And teach my sword to hurt that that preserved me?
Though I be rough by nature, shall my name
Inherit that eternal stain of barbarous?
Give me an enemy, a thing that hates ye,
That never heard of yet, nor felt your goodness,
That is one main antipathy to sweetness;
And set me on, you cannot hold me coward:
If I have ever erred, 'th as in hazard:
The temper of my sword starts at your virtue,
And will fly off, nay it will weep to light ye;
Things excellently mingled, and of pure nature,
Hold sacred love, and peace with one another.
See how it turns.

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: This is a strange conversion:
And can ye fail your mistress? can ye grow cold
In such a case?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Those heats that they add to us,
(Oh noble Pedro) let us feel 'em rightly,
And rightly but consider how they move us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is not their honour ours?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If they be virtuous;
And then the sword adds nothing to their lustre,
But rather calls in question what's not doubted:
If they be not: the best swords, and best valours
Can never fight 'em up to fame again:
No, not a Christian war, and that's held pious.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How bravely now he is tempered? I must fight,
And rather make it honourable, then angry,
I would not task those sins to me committed.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You cannot sir: you have cast those by; discarded 'em,
And in a noble mind, so low and loosely
To look back, and collect such lumps, and lick 'em
Into new horrid forms again.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Still braver.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: To fight, because I dare, were worse, and weaker
Than if I had a woman in my cause, sir,
And more proclaimed me fool; yet I must confess
I have been covetous of all occasions,
And this I have taken upon trust, for noble,
The more shame mine; devise a way to fight thus,
That like the wounded air no blood may issue,
Nor where this sword shall enter, no lost spirit,
And set me on: I would not scar that body,
That virtuous, valiant body, nor deface it
To make the kingdom mine: if one must bleed,
Let me be both the sacrifice, and altar,
And you the priest: I have deserved to suffer.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The noble Roderigo, now I call ye,
And thus my love shall ever count, and hold ye,
I am your servant sir: and now this habit,
Devotion, not distrust shall put upon me,
I'll wait upon your fortunes, that's my way now,
And where your grief, or joy, I'll be a partner.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I thank ye sir, I shall be too proud of ye,
Oh I could tell ye strange things.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I guess at 'em,
And I could curse myself, I made 'em stranger;
Yet my mind says, you are not far from happiness.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It shall be welcome; come, let's keep us thus still,
And be as we appear: heaven's hand may bless us.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Yes sir, here be such people: but how pleasing,
They will appear to you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pray let me see 'em,
I come to that end: pray let me see 'em all.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They will confound ye sir, like bells rung backward
They are nothing but confusion, and mere noises.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: May be I love a noise: but hark ye sir,
Have ye no boys, handsome young boys?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Yes one sir,
A very handsome boy.

sp.speaker: Alp
sp.l: Long here?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: But two days;
A little crazed: but much hope of recovery.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I that boy, let me see: may be I know him;
That boy, I say: this is the boy he told me of,
And it must needs be she: that boy I beseech ye sir,
That boy I come to see.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: And ye shall see him:
Or any else, but pray be not too violent.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I know what to do, I warrant ye: I am for all fancies:
I can talk to 'em, and dispute.

sp.speaker: 1 keeper
sp.l: As madly:
For they be very mad sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Let 'em be horn mad.

sp.speaker: 1. keeper
sp.l: We have few citizens: they have bedlams of their own sir,
And are mad at their own charges.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Who lies here?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray ye do not disturb sir, here lie such youths
Will make you start if they but dance their trenchmores.
Fetch out the boy, sirrah: hark. Shake irons within.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Heigh boys. Engl. mad-m.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Bounce,Scholar, parson.
Clap her o'th starboard: bounce: top the can, Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Scholar
sp.l: Dead ye dog, dead: do ye quarrel in my kingdom?
Give me my trident.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Bounce, 'twixt wind and water,
Loaden with mackerels: oh brave meat.

sp.speaker: Scholar
sp.l: My sea horses.
I'll charge the Northern wind, and break his bladder.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: I'll sell my bells, before I be outbraved thus.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What's he? what's he?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A parson sir, a parson,
That run mad for tithe goslings.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Green sauce cure him.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: I'll curse ye all, I'll excommunicate ye:
Thou English heretic, give me the tenth pot.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Sue me, I'll drink up all, bounce I say once more,
Oh, have I split your mizzen? blow, blow thou West wind,
Blow till thou rive, and make the sea run roaring.
I'll hiss it down again with a bottle of ale.

sp.speaker: Scholar
sp.l: Triton, why Triton.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Triton's drunk with metheglin.

sp.speaker: Scholar
sp.l: Strike, strike the surges, strike.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Drink, drink, 'tis day light;
Drink, diddle, diddle, diddle, drink, parson, proud parson:
A pig's tail in thy teeth, and I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: Give me some porridge, or I'll damn thee English.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: How comes this English mad man here?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Alas that's no question:
They are mad everywhere sir;
Their fits are cool now: let 'em rest. Enter keepers and shee-foole.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Mad gallants:
Most admirable mad: I love their faces.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: Ye stinking whore: who knew of this? who looked to him?
Pox take him, he was sleepy when I left him,

sp.speaker: 2. K.
sp.l: Certain he made the fool drunk.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: How now who's this here?
Where is the boy?

sp.speaker: 1. keeper
sp.l: The boy sir?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I the boy, sir.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: Here's all the boys we found.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: These are his clothes.
But where's the boy?

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: The boy is gone a-maying,
He'll bring me home a cuckoo's nest; do ye hear master
I put my clothes off, and I dizened him,
And pinned a plumb in's forehead, and a feather,
And bussed him twice, and bid him go seek his fortune:
He gave me this fine money, and fine wine too,
And bid me sop: and gave me these trim clothes too,
And put 'em on.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is this the boy you would show?

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: I'll give you two pence master.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Am I fooled of all sidies?
I met a fool i'th woods, they said she dwelled here,
In a long pied coat.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: That was the very boy, sir.

sp.speaker: She. F.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, I gave him leave to play forsooth,
He'll come again tomorrow, and bring peascods.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I'll bring your bones.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pox of your fools, and bedlams,
Plague of your owls and apes.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray ye sir, be tamer,
We cannot help this presently: but we shall know;
I'll recompense your cares too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Know me a pudding.
You juggle, and ye fiddle: fart upon ye:
I am abused.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray ye sir. Welch madman.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And I will be abused sir,
And yond shall know I am abused.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Whaw, Mr. keeper.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pox of thy whawes, and thy whims,
Pox of thy worship.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Give me some hee●e, and onions: give me some washbrew,
I have — in my bellies: give me abundance,
Pendragon was a gentleman, marg you sir,
And the organs at rixum were made by revelations,
There is a spirit blows, and blows the bellows,
And then they sing.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What moon-calf's this? what dream?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray ye sir observe him,
He is a mountaineer, a man of Goteland.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I will beat thy face as black as a blew-clout,
I will leave no more sheet in thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He will not hurt ye.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Give me a great deal of guns: thou art the devils,
I know thee by thy tails: poor Owen's hungry,
I will pig thy bums full of bullets.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: This is the rarest rascal,
He speaks as if he had buttermilk in's mouth,
Is this any thing a kin to th' English?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The elder brother, sir,
He run mad because a rat eat up's cheese.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: He'd a great deal of reason sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Basilus manus, is for an old codpiece, mark ye,
I will borrow thy unships whore, to seal a letter.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now he grows villainous.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Methinks he's best now.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: He shall not.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Sir, he must.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I will sing, and dance:
Do any thing.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Wilt thou declaim in greek?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Away with the fool,
And whip her soundly sirrah.

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: I'll tell no more tales.Exit

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Or wilt thou fly i'th air?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Do, and I'll catch thee,
And like a wisp of hay, I'll whirl, and whirl thee,
And puss thee up: and puff thee up.

sp.speaker: Scholar
sp.l: I'll save thee,
And thou shalt fall into the sea, soft, softly.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I'll get upon a mountain and call my countrymen.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They all grow wild: away with him for heaven's sake,
Sir, ye are much too blame.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis brave sir,
Ye have cozened me; I'll make you mad.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: In with him,
And lock him fast.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I'll see him in his lodging.Exit

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: What means this gentleman? En. Julletta

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He's in: have at him,
Are you the master, sir?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: What would you with him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have a business from the Duke of Medina,
Is there not an old gentleman come lately in?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Yes, and a wild one too; but not a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Did you observe him well? 'tis like he may be.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I have seen younger men of better temper.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have hit the cause I come for: there's a letter
Pray ye peruse it well: I shall be with ye;
And suddenly, I fear not: finely, daintily,
I shall so feed your fierce vexation,
And raise your worship's storms: i shall so niggle ye,
And juggle ye, and fiddle ye, and firk ye:
I'll make ye curse the hour yet vexed a woman;
I'll make ye stake, when our sex, are but sounded:
For the lords sake, we shall have him at; I long to see it
As much as for my wedding night: I gape after it.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This letter says the gentleman is lunatic
I half suspected it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis very true sir,
And such pranks he has played.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He's some great man,
The Duke commands me with such care to look to him,
And if he grow too violent, to correct him,
To use the speediest means for his recovery,
And those he must find sharp.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The better for him:

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: How got ye him hither?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: With a train, I told him:
He's in love with a boy, there lies his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Hither he came to seek one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, i sent him,
Now had we dealt by force, we had never brought him.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Here was a boy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He saw him not?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He was gone first.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is the better; look you to your charge well:
I'll see him lodged, for so the Duke commanded me
He will be very rough.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We are used to that sir,
And we as rough as he, if he give occasion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You will find him gainful, but be sure ye curb him,
And get him if ye can fairly to his lodging,Enter Alphonso.
I am afraid ye will not.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We must sweat then.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What dost thou talk to me of noises? I'll have more noise
I'll have all loose, and all shall play their prizes;
Thy master has let loose the boy I looked for
Basely conveyed him hence.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Will ye go out sir?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I will not out: I will have all out with 'Me,Shake irons
I'll have thy master in; he's only mad here.
And rogues, I'll have ye all whipped: heigh mad boys, mad boys.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Do you perceive him now?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: 'Tis too apparent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am glad she is gone: he raves thus.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Do you hear sir,
Pray will ye make less stir, and see your chamber,
Call in more help; and make the closet ready.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: I thought he was mad: I'll have one long lash at ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: My chamber? where my chamber why my chamber
Where's the young boy?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Nay pray ye sir be more modest
For your own credit's sake: the people see ye,
And I would use ye with the best.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Best, hang ye
What dost thou think me mad?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray, and be civil,
Heaven may deliver ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Into a rogue's hands.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You do but draw more misery upon ye,
And add to your disease.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Get from me.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: No sir,
You must not be left so: bear yourself civilly,
And 'twill be better for ye: swell not, nor chafe not.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I am a gentleman, and a neighbour, rascal.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A great deal the more pity: I have heard of ye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Excellent master.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The Duke is very tender too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Am I lunatic? am I run mad?
What dost thou talk to me of Dukes, and devils,
Why do the people gape so?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Do not anger 'em,
But go in quietly, and slip in softly
They will so tew ye, else, I am commanded sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why, prithee why?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ye are dog-mad: you perceive it not
Very far mad: and whips will scant recover ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Ha ▪ whips?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I whips, and sore whips, and ye were a lord sir,
If ye be stubborn here:

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Whips? what am I grown.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O I could burst: hold, hold, hold, hold o'both ends,
How he looks, pray heaven, he be not mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I do not perceive I am so; but if you think it,
Nor I ▪ le be hanged if't be so.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Do you see this sir? Irons brought in
Down with that devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Indeed I am angry,
But I'll contain myself: oh I could burst now,
And tear myself, but these rogues will torment me,
Mad in mine old days? make mine own afflictions?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: What do you mutter sir?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nothing, sir, nothing;
I will go in, and quietly, most civilly:
And good sir, let none of your tormentors come about me,
You have a gentle face; they look like dragons.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Be civil and be safe: come, for these two days
Ye must eat nothing neither: 'twill ease your fits sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Twill starve me sir; but I must bear it joyfully.
I may sleep?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Yes, a little: go in with these men.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O miserable me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I'll follow presently.
You see 'tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye have done it handsomely,
And I'll inform the Duke so: pray ye attend him;
Let him want nothing, but his will.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He shall not,
And if he be rebellious —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Never spare him:
Has flesh, and hide enough, he loves a whipping.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: My service to his grace. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I shall commend it.
So, thou art fast: I must go get some fresh room
To laugh, and caper in: oh how it tickles me!
O how it tumbles me with joy! thy mouths stopped:
Now if I can do my mistress good, I am sainted. Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, of my conscience, we have lost him utterly,
He's not gone home: we heard from thence this morning,
And since our parting last at Rodorigo's,
You know what ground we have travelled.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He's asleep sure:
For if he had been awake, we should have met with him:
I'faith let's turn back, we have but a fruitless journey;
And to hope further of Alinda's recovery,
(For sure she'll rather perish than return)
Is but to seek a moth i'th sun.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We'll on sure;
Something we'll know, some cause of all this fooling,
Make some discovery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Which way shall we cast then,
For all the champion country, and the villages,
And all those sides?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We'll cross these woods a while then:
Here if we fail, we'll gallop to Segonia
Add if we light of no news there, hear nothing;
We'll even turn fairly home, and coast the other side.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He may be sick, or fallen into some danger;
He has no guide, nor no man to attend him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He's well enough, he has a travelled body,
And though he be old, he's tough, and will endure well;
But he is so violent to find her out,
That his anger leads him a thousand wild goose chases:
I'll warrant he is well.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Shall we part company?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: By no means, no: that were a sullen business:
No pleasure in our journey: come, let's cross here first,
And where we find the paths, let them direct us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why are you still so fearful of me, lady?
So doubtful of my faith, and honest service?
To hide yourself from me, to fly my company?
Am I not yours? all yours? by this light you shake still;
Do ye suspect me false? did I ever fail ye?
Do you think I am corrupted? base? and treacherous?
Lord, how ye look! Is not my life tied to ye?
And all the power I have to serve, and honour ye?
Still do ye doubt? still am I terrible?
I will not trouble ye: good heaven preserve ye,
And send ye what ye wish: I will not see ye,
Nor once remember I had such a mistress.
I will not speak of ye, nor name Alinda,
For fear you should suspect I would betray ye:
Goodness and peace conduct ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prithee pardon me,
I know thou art truly faithful: and thou art welcome,
A welcome partner to my miseries;
Thou knowest I love thee too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have thought so, lady.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas, my fears have so distracted me
I durst not trust myself.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, pray ye think better,
And cast those by: at least consider, lady,
How to prevent 'em: pray ye put off this fool's coat;
Though it have kept ye secret for a season,
'Tis known now, and will betray ye; your arch enemy
Roderigo is abroad: many are looking for ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I know it: and those many I have cozened:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You cannot still thus.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I have no means to shift it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have: and shift you too. I lay last night
At a poor widow's house here in the thicket,
Whether I will conduct ye, and new shape ye,
Myself too to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What means hast thou?
For mine are gone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fear not, enough to serve ye;
I came not out so empty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prithee tell me;
(For thou hast stroke a kind of comfort through me.)
When sawest thou Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Even this morning,
And in these woods: take heed, has got a new shape.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: The habit of a pilgrim? yes, I know it,
And I hope shall prevent it; was he alone?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No madam, and which made me wonder mightily,
He was in company with that handsome pilgrim,
That sad sweet man.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: That I forgotten to give to?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The same, the very same, that you so pitied,
A man as fit to suit his villainies.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And did they walk together?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wondrous civilly.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Talk, and discourse?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I think so, for I see 'em
Make many stands, and then embrace each other.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: The pilgrim is betrayed, a Judas dwells with him,
A Simon, that will seem a saint to choke him.
Canst thou but show me this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Lord how she trembles!
Not thus, for all the world, ye are undone then;
But let's retire, and alter, then we'll walk free;
And then I'll show ye any things.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Come, good wench,
And speedily: for I have strange faiths working,
As strange fears too, I'll tell thee all my life then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come quick, I'll conduct ye, and still serve ye,
And do not fear; hang fear, it spoils all projects.
This way; I'll be your guide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Use all your sports,
All your solemnities; 'tis the King's day tomorrow.
His birth day, and his marriage, a glad day,
A day we ought to honour, all.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: We will sir,
And make Segonia ring with our rejoicings.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Be sumptuous, but not riotous; be bounteous,
But not in drunken bacchanals: free to all strangers,
Easy, and sweet in all your entertainments,
For 'tis a royal day admits no rudeness.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: Your lordship will do us the honour to be here yourself,
And grace the day?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: 'Tis a main part of my service.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: I hope your honour has taken into your consideration
The miseries we have suffered by these outlaws,
The losses, hourly fears; the rude abuses
Strangers that travel to us are daily loaden with
Our daughters, and our wives complaints.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I am sorry for't,
And have commission from the King to ease it:
You shall not be long vexed.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: Had we not walls, sir,
And those continually maned too with our watches,
We should not have a bit of meat to feed us.
And yet they are our friends, and we must think so,
And entertain 'em so sometimes, and feast 'em,
And send 'em laden home too, we are lost else.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: They'll come to church amongst us, as we hope Christians,
When all their zeal is but to steal the chalices;
At this good time now, if your lordship were not here,
To awe their violence with your authority,
They would play such gambols.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Are they grown so heady?

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: They would drink up all our wine, piss out our bonfires;
Then, like the drunken centaurs, have at the fairest,
Nay, have at all: fourscore and ten's a goddess,
Whilst we, like fools, stand shaking in our cellars.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Are they so fierce upon so little sufferance?
I'll give 'em such a purge, and suddenly.
Verdugo, after this solemnity is over
Call on me for a charge of men, of good men,
To see what house these knaves keep: of good soldiers,
As sturdy as themselves: that dare dispute with 'em,
Dare walk the woods as well as they, as fearless,
But with a better faith belabour 'em;
I'll know what claim they have to their possession.
'Tis pity of their captain Roderigo,
A wellbred gentleman, and a good soldier,
And one, his majesty has some little reason
To thank, for sundry services, and fair ones;
That long neglect bred this, I am sorry for him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The hope of his estate keeps back his pardon,
There's divers wasps, that buzz about that honey-box,
And long to lick themselves full.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: True Verdugo,
Would he had but the patience to discern it,
And policy to wipe their lips.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: To fetch him in sir,
By violence, he being now no insane,
Will ask some bloody crowns. I know his people.
Are of his own choice men, that will not totter,
Nor blench much at a bullet; I know his order,
And though he have no multitude, has manhood;
The elder-twin to that too, staid experience.
But if he must be forced, sir, —

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: There's no remedy,
Unless he come himself.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That will be doubtful.
Did you never hear yet of the noble Pedro?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I cannot by no means; I think he's dead sure;
The court bewails much his untimely loss:
The King himself laments him.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: He was sunk;
And if he be dead, he died happily,
He buried all he had in the King's service,
And lost himself.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Well: if he be alive, captain,
(As hope still speaks the best) I know the King's mind
So inwardly and full, he will be happy.
Come, to this preparation; when that's done,
The outlaws expedition is begun.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: We'll contribute all to that, and help ourselves too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How sweet these solitary places are? how wantonly
The wind blows through the leaves, and courts, and plays with 'em?
Will ye sit down, and sleep? the heat invites ye.
Hark how yond purling stream dances, and murmurs,
The birds sing softly too: pray take some rest, sir.
I would fain woo his fancy to a peace,
It labours high and hastily upon him;
Pray ye sit, and I'll sit by.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot sleep friend,
I have those watches here admit no slumbers.
Saw ye none yet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No creature.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What strange music
Was that we heard afar off?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I cannot guess;
'Twas loud, and shrill: sometimes it showed hard by us,
And by and by the sound fled as the wind does;
Here's no inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It much delighted me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They talk of fairies, and such demi-devils,
This is as fine a place to dance their gambols. —

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: methought I heard a voice. Music and birds.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They can sing admirably,
They never lose their maidenheads: I would fool any away
To make him merry now: methinks yond rocks yonder
Show like enchanted cells, where they inhabit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis here again, hark gentle Roderigo,
Hark, hark: oh sweet, sweet, how the birds record too!
Mark how it flies now every way. O love,
In such a harmony art thou begotten,
In such soft air, so gentle, lullled and nourished.
O my best mistress!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How he weeps! dear heaven
Give him his heart's content, and me forgive too.
I must melt too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The birds sing louder, sweeter,
And every note they emulate one another?
Lie still and hear: these when they have done their labours,
sp.stage: Enter Alinda and Juletta, like old women.
sp.l: Their pretty airs, fall to their rests, enjoy 'em.
Nothing rocks love asleep, but death.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Who are these?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Those there, those, those things that come upon us,
Those grandam things, those strange antiquities.
Did not I say these words begotten strange wonders?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now ye may view 'em.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The men ye longed for,
Here they are both: now ye may boldy talk with 'em,
And never be guessed at: be not afraid, nor faint not;
They wonder at us; let's maintain that wonder;
Shake not, but what ye purpose do discreetly,
And from your tongue I'll take my part.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: There: before ye, there, do not turn coward mistress,
If ye do love, carry your love out handsomely.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: 'Tis he and Roderigo; what a peace
Dwells in their faces, what a friendly calm
Crowns both their souls?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They show as if they were mortal,
They come upon us still.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Be not afraid, man,
Let 'em be what they will, they cannot hurt us,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That thing ith' buttoned-cap looks terribly.
She has guns in her eyes, the devil's engineer.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come, stand, and let's go meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Go you first.
I have less faith: when I have said my prayers —

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There needs no fear, hail reverend dames.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Good e'en.
What do ye seek?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We would seek happier fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That little devil has main need of a barber,
What a trim beard she has?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Seek 'em, and make 'em,
Lie not still, nor longer here,
Here inhabits naught but fear.
Be constant good, in faith be clear,
Fortune will wait ye everywhere .

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Whether should we go? for we believe thy reverence,
And next obey.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Go to Segonia.
And there before the altar pay thy vows,
Thy gifts, and prayers: unload thy heaviness,
Tomorrow shed thy tears, and gain thy suit,
Such honest noble showers, never wanted fruit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand you out too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I shall be hanged, or whipped now:
These know, and these have power.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: See how he shakes.
A secure conscience never quakes,
Thou hast been ill; be so no more,
A good retreat is a great store.
Thou hast commanded men of might,
Command thyself, and than thou art right,

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Command thy will: thy foul desires.
Put out and quench thy unhallowed fires:
Command thy mind, and make that pure;
Thou art wise then, valiant, and secure.
A blessing than thou mayst beget.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A curse else that shall never set
Will light upon thee: say thy prayers,
Thou hast as many sins, as hairs.
Thou art a captain, let thy men
Be honest, and good thoughts, and than
Thou mayst command, and lead in chief,
Yet thou art bloody, and a thief.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What shall do? I do confess.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Retire,
And purge thee perfect in his fire:
His life observe; live in his school,
And than thou shalt put off the fool.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray at Segonia too, and give
Thy offerings up, repent, and live.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Away, away: inquire no more, within music
Do this, ye are rich, else fools, and poor;
What music's this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Retire? 'tis some neat joy,
In honour of the Kings great day: they wonder,
This comes in right to confirm their reverence.
Away, away, let them admire, it makes
For our advantage: how the captain shakes? Exit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This was the music.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes, yes, how I sweat!
I was never so deserted; sure these woods
Are only inhabited with rare dreams, and wonders;
I would not be a knave again, a villain:
Lord, how I loathe it now: for these know all sir,
And they would find me out.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They are excellent women,
Deep in their knowledge, friend.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I would not be traitor,
And have these of my jury; how light I am,
And how my heart laughs now methinks within me?
Now I am catechised, I would ever dwell here,
For there is a kind of court of reformation;
Had I been stubborn friend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They would have found it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And then they would have handled me a new way,
The devil's dump had been danced then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let's away
And do their great commands, and do 'em handsomely:
Contrite, and true, for I believe Roderigo,
And constantly believe, we shall be happy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So you do well; fall edge or flat oh my side;
All I can stagger at is the King's anger,
Which if it come, I am prepared to meet it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The King has mercy, friend, as well as justice:
And when you fall: no more.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I hope the fairest. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: We have told ye what he is: what time we have sought him:
His nature, and his name: the seeming boy too,
Ye had here, how, and what by your own relation,
All circumstances we have cleared: that the Duke sent him
We told ye how impossible; he knows him not;
That he is mad himself, and therefore fit
To be your prisoner, we dare swear against it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Take heed sir, be not madder than you would make him;
Though he be rash, and sudden (Which is all his wildness)
Take heed ye wrong him not: he is a gentleman,
And so must be restored and cleared in all points;
The King shall be a judge else.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: 'Twas some trick
That brought him hither: the boy, and letter counterfeit,
Which shall appear, if ye dare now detain him.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I dare not sir; nor will not: I believe ye,
And will restore him up: had I known sooner
He'd been a neighbour, and the man you speak him,
(Though as I live, he carried a wild seeming)
My service, and myself had both attended him
How I have used him, let him speak.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let's in, and visit him:
Then to the holy temple: there pay our duties,
And so we'll take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I'll wait upon ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena sexta.
div.stage: Enter governor, Verdugo, courtiers, ladies, etc.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: This to devotion sacred be,
This to the King's prosperity,
This to the Queen, and chastity. Music.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: These oblations first we bring
To purge ourselves: these to the King.
To love, and beauty these: now sing. Music.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: Holy altar, deign to take
These for ourselves: for the King's sake
And honour these: these sacred lie
To virtue, love, and modesty
Our wishes to eternity. Music. Enter Pedro and Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: For ourselves first, thus we bend
Forgive us heaven, and be our friend:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And happy fortune to us send.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To the King, honour, and all joy,
Long, and happy from annoy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Prosperous be all his days
Every new hour, a new praise.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Every minute thus be seen,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: And thousand honours crown the Queen. Music. Enter Alphonso, Curio, Seberto.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come to the altar: let, us do our duties.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have almost forgotten a church.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Kneel reverently.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: For my lost wits (Let me see)
First i pray: and secondly
To be at home again, and free,
And if I travel more, hang me,
For the King, and for the Queen,
That they may be wise, and seen
Never in the madman's inn.
For my daughter, I would pray
But she has made a holiday,
And needs not my devotion now
Let her take her own course (Heaven,)
Whether it be odd, or even. Music. Enter Alinda, and Juletta like shepherds.
And if that please not, take her you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A short, and sweet meditation: what are these here?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Haile to this sacred place,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are all here, madam:
No violence dare touch here; be secure:
My bilbo master too: how got he loose again?
How lamentably he looks: he has had discipline.
I dare not let him know my pranks.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis she sure.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: 'Tis certainly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha! do I dazzle?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis the fair Alinda.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What wonder stand these strangers in?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Her woman by her,
The same sir, as I live,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I had a daughter,
With such a face once: such eyes and nose too,
Ha, let me see, 'tis wondrous like Alinda,
Their devotion ended, I'll mark 'em and nearer.
And she had a filly that waited on her:
Just with such a favour,
Do they keep goats now?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thus we kneel, and thus we pray
A happy honour, to this day,
Thus our sacrifice we bring
Ever happy to the King.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: These of purple, damask green
Sacred, to the virtuous Queen
Here we hang.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: As these are now
Her glories ever spring, and show,
These for ourselves: our hopes, and loves,
Full of pinks, and ladies' gloves,
Of heart's-ease too, which we would feign
As we labour for, attain;
Hear me heaven, and as I bend,
Full of hope: some comfort send.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hear her: hear her: if there be
A spotless sweetness, this is she. Music.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now Roderigo stand.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He that divides ye
Divides my life too.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Pedro, noble Pedro.
Do not you know your friend?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: I know, and honour ye.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Lady this leave I'll crave, pray be not angry,
I will not long divide you: how happy Pedro,
Would all the court be now, might they be thee?
Might they but see you thus and thus embrace you?
The King will be a joyful man believe it
Most joyful Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am his humble servant.
Nay, good sir, speak your will, I see you wonder, one easy word from you —

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I dare say nothing
My tongue's a new tongue sir, and knows his tither,
Let her do what she please, I dare do nothing,
I have been damned for doing, will the King know him?
That fellow there, will he respect and honour him?
He has been looked upon they say: will he own him?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Yes certainly and grace him, ever honour him,
Restore him every way, he has much lamented him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is't your will too? this is the last time of asking.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I am sure, none else shall touch her, none else enjoy her.
If this, and this hold.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: You had best begin the game then, I have no title in her,
Pray take her, and dispatch her, and commend me to her,
And let me get me home, and hope I am sober:
Kiss, kiss, it must be thus: stand up Alinda,
I am the more child, and more need of blessing.
Ye had a waiting woman, one Juletta,
A pretty desperate thing, just such another
As this sweet lady; we called her nimble chaps.
I pray is this the party?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No indeed sir,
She is at home; I am a little footboy,
That walk a nights, and fright old gentlemen;
Make 'em lose hats and cloaks.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And horses too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sometimes I do sir, teach 'em the way through ditches;
And how to break their worship's skins, and notes
Against old broken styles, and Stumps.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A fine art.
I feel it in my bones yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am a drum sir,
A drum at midnight, ran tan tan tan tan sir,
Do you take me for Juletta? I am a page sir,
That brought a letter from the Duke of Medina
To have one senior Alphonso, just such another
As your old worship wormed for running mad sir.
Alas, you are mistaken,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou art the devil,
And so thou hast used me,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am any thing,
An old woman, that tells fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: And frights good people,
And sends them to Segonia for their fortunes:
I am strange airs, and excellent sweet voices.
I am any thing, to do her good believe me;
She now recovered, and her wishes crowned
I am Juletta again, pray sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I dare not do otherwise, for fear thou shouldst still follow me,
Prithee be forgiven, and I prithee forgive me too:
And if any of you, will marry her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No I beseech you sir;
My mistress is my husband, with her I'll dwell still,
And when you play any more pranks you know where to have me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: You know him sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Know him, and much lament him:
The Kings incensed much, much sir, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Noble governor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: But since he is your friend, and now appears,
In honour of this day and love to you sir:
I'll try the power I have, to the pinch I'll put it;
Here's my hand Roderigo, I'll set you fair again.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And here's mine, to be true, and full of service.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Your people too, shall have their general pardons,
We'll have all peace and love.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: All shall pray for you.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: To my house now, and suit you to your worths;
Off with these weeds, and appear glorious:
Then to the priest, that shall attend us here,
And this be styled loves new and happy year.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Kings and Queens, two noble honours meet,
To grace this day, two true loves at their feet

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well well, since wedding will come after wooing,
Give me some rosemary, and let's be going.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
